{{Infobox Person | name = Jono Bacon | image = Jonobacon.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1979|9|17|mf=y}} | caption = Jono giving a speech at the O'Reilly Conference | occupation = [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] Community Manager | website = [http://www.jonobacon.org/ www.jonobacon.org] | footnotes = }} '''Jono Bacon''' (full name '''Jonathan Edward James Bacon'''<ref>According to a June 17, 2007 [[podcast]] from [[LugRadio]]: http://www.lugradio.org/episodes/80</ref><ref>According to his own web log: http://www.jonobacon.org/?p=576</ref>) is a [[community manager]], [[writer]], [[musician]] and [[software developer]], originally from the [[United Kingdom]], but now based in [[California]]. Bacon is a prominent speaker on [[community management]], works as the [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] Community Manager for [[Canonical Ltd.]], authored ''The Art of Community'' by O'Reilly<ref name="ArtofComm"> {{cite web|url = http://www.artofcommunityonline.org/|title = Art Of Community Online|accessdate = 2009-01-29|last = Bacon|first = Jono|authorlink = |year = 2009|month = January}}</ref> and is the founder and organizer of the annual ''Community Leadership Summit''<ref>http://www.communityleadershipsummit.com/about/</ref><ref name="Paul24Jun08">{{Cite news|url = http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2008/06/ubuntu-community-head-tests-music-economics-with-open-content.ars|title = Ubuntu community head tests music economics with open content|accessdate = 5 August 2011|last = Paul|first = Ryan|authorlink = |year = 2008|month = June| work = [[Ars Technica]]}}</ref>.
== History ==
Bacon started his work with the [[Linux]] community when he created the UK Linux website, Linux UK <ref>According to his own web log: http://www.jonobacon.org/2007/06/05/remembering-the-building-blocks/</ref>. When he left this project he moved on to join the [[KDE]] team, where he created the KDE::Enterprise website and KDE Usability Study. He was also been involved with helping charities using [[free software]], was a participant in [[LugRadio]] and founded ''Wolverhampton Linux Users' Group''. Additionally, he has created a heavy rock version of the [[Free Software Song]]<ref>http://www.jonobacon.org/2011/06/15/metal-free-software-song-2-this-time-its-personal/</ref>.
Bacon started his career as a Linux journalist before moving on in 2006 to work for OpenAdvtantage<ref>http://www.jonobacon.org/2004/10/28/</ref> to help move organizations to Open Source solutions. On September 4, 2006, he started work for [[Canonical Ltd.]] as the [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] Community Manager<ref>http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/53</ref><ref>Amber Graner (2010) â[http://www.ubuntu-user.com/Magazine/Archive/2010/6/INTERVIEW-JONO-BACON-UBUNTU-COMMUNITY-MANAGER Interview: Jono Bacon, Ubuntu Community Manager]â ''Ubuntu User'' Issue 6 pp 8-9</ref>.
== Community Management ==
In recent years Bacon has become a prominent speaker and consultant on building communities and community management. He has authored ''The Art of Community'' by O'Reilly, is the founder and organizer of the annual ''Community Leadership Summit'', an annual meeting point for community leaders, and writes regularly about community leadership on his blog<ref>http://www.jonobacon.org</ref>
== Journalism ==
As a professional [[journalist]], Bacon has written for a variety of publications<ref>http://www.jonobacon.org/about/</ref>, including ''[[Linux User and Developer]]'', ''[[Linux Format]]'', ''[[Linux Magazine]]'', ''[[MacTech]]'', ''[[MacFormat]]'' and ''[[PC Plus]]''. In addition to these magazines, he has also written a number of books, including "The Art of Community", "Linux Desktop Hacks"<ref>http://oreilly.com/catalog/9780596009113</ref>, "PHP and MySQL Web Applications: Building Eight Dynamic Web Sites"<ref>http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/Practical-PHP-and-MySQL-Building-Eight-Dynamic-Web-Applications/9780132239974.page</ref> and he also co-wrote "The Official Ubuntu Book" (ISBN 0-13-243594-2) with [[Benjamin Mako Hill]], Corey Burger, and Jonathan Jesse.
Bacon was the co-founder of the [[LugRadio]] podcast and live events and the only member to appear on every show. He had also been a regular co-host on [[FLOSS Weekly]] starting with episode 69, even filling in for [[Randal Schwartz]] when Randal was not available.<ref>[http://twit.tv/floss FLOSS Weekly home page]</ref> When FLOSS Weekly moved to a new morning timeslot, Jono was unable to make the transition. Bacon also founded the Shot Of Jaq podcast with [[Stuart Langridge]] and the show ran for a short period<ref>http://shotofjaq.org/about/</ref>.
== Public Speaking ==
Bacon has presented at many events, including: [[Ohio Linux Fest]]<ref>http://lwn.net/Articles/293165/</ref>, [[Southern California Linux Expo]]<ref>http://www.socallinuxexpo.org/scale6x/conference-info/speakers/Jono-Bacon/</ref>, MySQL Conference<ref>http://en.oreilly.com/mysql2010/public/schedule/detail/14796</ref>, OSBC<ref>https://www.eiseverywhere.com/ehome/index.php?eventid=7578&tabid=4152</ref>, Linux User & Developer Conference, Blender Conference, IBM Linux Migration Seminar, European Friends Of OâReilly, d:CODE, Association For Free Software Conference, [[SkyCon]], UKUUG Conference West Midlands IT Association, [[OSS Watch]] Conference, IBM Developer Workshop, Python UK 2007 (after dinner speech), various [[LUG]]s, as well as the LUGRadio Live events of which he was a principal organiser. He also presented the Keynote at the "10 years KDE" anniversary conference in Ostfildern, Germany<ref>http://events.kde.org/10years/</ref>.
== Music ==
Bacon has had a long interest in music. He started playing in Conspiracy, followed by Neuraxon. He was the vocalist and a rhythm guitarist in ''Seraphidian''<ref>http://www.metal-archives.com/bands/Seraphidian/2944</ref>. His website includes a number of songs that he has recorded separately from the band, including the aforementioned version of the [[Free Software Song]]. Bacon has also inspired an audio recording application called [[Jokosher]], a pun on the fact that his name contains the phrase [[kosher|"no bacon"]].
In June 2008 Bacon started a new musical project called ''[[Severed Fifth]]''. The aim was to produce an album in his home studio and then to distribute the music in new ways. This was an experiment in how musicians can work in the internet era, outside the conventional music industry. The first demo ''Denied By Reign'' was released 21 October 2008 and features brutal [[death metal]]. His second album ''Nightmares by Design'', more [[melodic death metal]] in style, was released on 11 October 2010.<ref name="Paul24Jun08" /><ref name="SeveredFifth"> {{cite web|url = http://www.severedfifth.com/releases/|title = Releases|accessdate = 2008-10-28|last = Bacon|first = Jono|authorlink = |year = 2008}}</ref>
